channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: India Ink: Once an Agitator, Now in Charge of Delhi’s Government
item.description: Though Arvind Kejriwal, and his Aam Aadmi Party were dismissed as political novices, they made a series of astute moves to upend the state assembly.
item.dc:creator: By VAIBHAV VATS
item.media:description: Arvind Kejriwal, leader of Aam Aadmi Party, after taking oath as the new chief minister of Delhi at the Ramlila grounds in New Delhi on Saturday.

item.title: Gunmen in Greece Attack German Ambassador’s Residence
item.description: No one claimed responsibility for the shooting on Monday but anti-German sentiment has been festering over a harsh austerity plan linked to Greece’s bailout.
item.dc:creator: By LIZ ALDERMAN

item.title: DealBook: On Defensive, JPMorgan Hired China’s Elite
item.description: Emails and documents suggest that competitive pressures drove many of the decisions by JPMorgan that are now under federal investigation.
item.dc:creator: By BEN PROTESS and JESSICA SILVER-GREENBERG
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: JPMorgan Chase's offices in Hong Kong. The bank and its rivals have hired well-connected employees in China.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese Women ‘Name and Shame’ Companies They Say Discriminate
item.description: By lodging formal complaints with local government alleging gender-based discrimination in how many Chinese companies hire, a group of women is drawing attention to a well-known problem largely hidden from public debate.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: An activist in Yunnan Province prepares to mail letters to her local government complaining of illegal gender discrimination by Chinese companies.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China Orders Officials to Stop Smoking in Public
item.description: Smoking is one of China’s most serious public health problems, and critics ask if the latest move to curb tobacco use will be any more effective than previous efforts.
item.dc:creator: By MIA LI
item.media:description: Delegates to a meeting at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing break for cigarettes.

item.title: Egypt Detains Journalists It Says Aired ‘False News’
item.description: The arrests of people working for the Al Jazeera English news channel appeared aimed at deterring journalists from reporting on the Muslim Brotherhood’s continuing protests.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: Second Blast Hits Russia, Raising Olympic Fears
item.description: A deadly blast on a trolley bus on Monday followed a suicide bombing at a railroad station a day earlier, underscoring the threat the country faces from a radical Islamic insurgency in the North Caucasus.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN LEE MYERS
item.media:description: At least 15 people were killed when an explosion ripped through a trolley bus in Volgograd on Monday.

item.title: Egypt Detains Journalists It Says Aired ‘False News’
item.description: The arrests of people working for the Al Jazeera English news channel appeared aimed at deterring journalists from reporting on the Muslim Brotherhood’s continuing protests.
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: The Death of a Family, and an American Dream
item.description: The divergent paths of two cousins — one on the way up, the other now charged with murder — lay bare the reality of life in New York’s Chinese community.
item.dc:creator: By VIVIAN YEE and JEFFREY E. SINGER
item.media:credit: Robert Stolarik for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yilin Zhuo held a photograph of his wife and four children at Forest Lawn Memorial Gardens Cemetery in Iselin, N.J., on Nov. 10.

item.title: The Cancer Divide: India’s Efforts to Aid Poor Worry Drug Makers
item.description: The government has threatened to allow production of less costly versions of a breast cancer treatment, a move the pharmaceutical industry says threatens the system for discovering cures.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: With Flowers, Ai Weiwei Protests His Loss of Freedom
item.description: Banned from leaving China for nearly three years now, the artist and dissident Ai Weiwei is protesting — by placing fresh flowers in the basket of a bicycle outside his studio in Beijing every day, he says.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: ‘Matchmaker’ Investment Agencies Help Open the Door to China
item.description: As China’s outbound direct investment increases and becomes ever more visible, times are good for third-party agencies that can bridge the cultural and linguistic gaps to reach Chinese investors.
item.dc:creator: By BREE FENG
item.media:description: The Beijing headquarters of China National Offshore Oil Corporation, whose $15.1 billion takeover of the Canadian oil and gas company Nexen was approved by the Canadian government in December 2012 and by United States regulators in February 2013.

item.title: Vito Rizzuto, Reputed Mafia Boss of Canada, Dies at 67
item.description: Mr. Rizzuto’s dapper outfits and his ability to avoid prison led the authorities to call him the John Gotti of Montreal.
item.dc:creator: By DANIEL E. SLOTNIK

item.title: U.S. Struggles to Keep Pace in Delivering Broadband Service
item.description: The United States is falling dangerously behind in offering high-speed, affordable broadband service, according to technology experts and recent studies.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WYATT
item.media:description: The capital city of Latvia, Riga, has an average Internet speed that is at least two-and-a-half times that of San Antonio.

item.title: In South Sudan Camp, Lives Compressed
item.description: As many as 22,000 people from around the world crammed into a United Nations peacekeeping base outside Malakal, South Sudan, are bound together by hunger, thirst and fear.
item.dc:creator: By NICHOLAS KULISH
item.media:description: Bradley Campbell, at center, took part in a prayer service at a United Nations camp for displaced people in Malakal.

item.title: Bombings Jolt Russia, Raising Olympic Fears
item.description: The explosion struck the main station in Volgograd, raising the specter of terrorism ahead of the Winter Olympics.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN LEE MYERS

item.title: Beirut Journal: Funeral Turnout Shows Lebanon’s Ebbing Morale
item.description: In a sign of how political passions have waned since mass protests help drive out the Syrians in 2005, barely 1,000 people attended the funeral of Mohamad B. Chatah, killed by a car bomb in Beirut on Friday.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: Relatives and friends of Mohamad B. Chatah mourned as his coffin was carried during his funeral procession in Martyr’s Square in Beirut, Lebanon, on Sunday.

item.title: Brazil Forging Economic Ties With Cuba, While Hiring Its Doctors
item.description: Brazil is vying to exert influence in Cuba as the authorities in Havana slowly expose the island nation’s economy to market forces.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO and VICTORIA BURNETT
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Idarmis González, seated, a Cuban doctor, spoke with the mother of an infant suffering from dehydration and diarrhea last month in the slum of Jacarezinho in Rio de Janeiro.

item.title: Second Icebreaker Nears Ship Stranded Off Antarctica
item.description: Strong winds last Tuesday packed loose ice around the ship, which is carrying researchers and tourists.
item.dc:creator: By HENRY FOUNTAIN
item.media:credit: Australian Maritime Safety Authority, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.media:description: The view from the Akademik Shokalskiy, stuck in pack ice near Cape de la Motte, Antarctica. An Australian icebreaker was in sight early Monday.

item.title: French ‘Millionaire Tax’ Cleared
item.description: The country’s Constitutional Council said the tax, on companies that pay annual salaries of more than 1 million euros, was legal.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Former Leader of Pakistan Denounces Treason Charges
item.description: The former military ruler Pervez Musharraf called the case the worst kind of “political vendetta” and claimed the country’s military establishment was upset by his treatment.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD
item.media:description: Pervez Musharraf, the former military ruler, addressed reporters at his home on the outskirts of Islamabad on Sunday.

item.title: Political Clashes Grow in Bangladesh’s Capital
item.description: The government closed most forms of transportation into the capital, arrested hundreds and barred the main opposition alliance from holding a protest rally.
item.dc:creator: By JULFIKAR ALI MANIK and GARDINER HARRIS
item.media:description: Supporters of the governing Awami League beat a supporter of the Bangladesh Nationalist Party at a protest in Dhaka on Sunday.

item.title: Syria Has Yet to Move Arms as Deadline Draws Near
item.description: Despite an international effort to mobilize the resources needed to do so, Syria has apparently not even begun to move its chemical weapons, observers familiar with the mission said.
item.category: Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: Egypt May Hold Presidential Vote Before Election of Parliament
item.description: The move, considered by the interim president, could lead to more control over the composition of Parliament, analysts say.
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: Rally Draws a Diverse Group of Protesters in Cambodia
item.description: The march included protesters with a diverse list of grievances: Buddhist monks, garment workers, farmers and supporters of the main opposition party.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:description: Protesters in the Cambodian capital included Buddhist monks, garment workers, farmers and supporters of the main opposition party.
